text: nearly 20,000 women gathered at a Tehran
Stadium last week to show their support
for iranian President Mahmoud
Ahmadinejad exactly at the same place
where a larger crowd came ten days
earlier to support mir hossein mousavi
the main challenger in the 2009
presidential election mr. Ahmadinejad
supporters are strongest in the villages
while mr. Mousavi's are concentrated in
the cities what I doubt since he's been
empowered there's been less crime that's
because of Ahmed in Ishod he takes care
of the cities and villages he cares
about the poor because he understands
the needs of people houses level
tomorrow ha mr. Ahmadinejad supporter
like these women clad in the traditional
head-to-toe adores carrying their
children were busting from around the
country most of them had letters for the
president stating their needs officials
were collecting the letters in big black
plastic bags throughout the event the
president patiently chatted with women
who pushed aside his bodyguards to hand
out the letters often written hastily on
the back of his campaign posters the
women interviewed praised mr.
Ahmadinejad saying he had responded to
their immediate financial needs hadfield
schools in their villages and paved
their roads on the contrary at rallies
last week mr. Mousavi supporters were
mostly young people from the cities who
wanted more social and political
freedoms as well as jobs
please add in guiding it the biggest
reason is mr. Mousavi's slogan justice
with freedom the greatest need of our
young people is freedom in our country
justice has lost its meaning we've never
seen wheel justice it's always been only
words mr. Mousavi along with two other
candidates have accused mr. Ahmadinejad
of wasting the state budgets on handouts
instead of investing it into development
projects that could create jobs we don't
want to regress we don't want to go
backwards we want to be modern we don't
want to step backward it's the 21st
century at the rallies mr. Mousavi
supporters have chanted we don't want a
potato government a reference to the
distribution of free potatoes around the
country by mr. Ahmadinejad people in the
cities have deemed such efforts as a way
to buy both ahead of the elections mr.
Ahmadinejad supporters said he
understood their needs the outcome of
the election remains unclear however
recent polls suggest a larger voter
turnout in the cities may increase mr.
Mousavi's chances in the elections for
the New York Times this is nazila fatty
intero
